children.subject: I know some people who got into the major for both 3.3 cap and 3.0 cap who had scores around 0.1 below the cap. If you applied already your personal statement should do the job, otherwise you would've to wait until next semester to apply
I had a 3.2 when I applied and I was accepted. I worked pretty hard on my personal statement and made sure that it showed the reasons why I should be in the CS program in a clear and articulate way.
Yup you’re guaranteed admission to the major by satisfying the GPA cutoff.
If we already have the GPA, then personal statement isn't really needed right?
I just wanted to say thanks for this. Regardless of making it into the major, it's nice to hear how our experiences in lower div courses don't necessarily set the tone for all of our future work.

I cannot agree more with you. I came with no knowledge of CS and very poor math background to Berkeley as ChemE and then changed into L&S to pursue CS after my first semester. I feel that the cap is more doable if you know you want to do CS from the get go, especially if you have previous experience. It is a bit unfair because if you had no experience and get a B in 61a it's going to be an upslope battle where you will have to get a B+ and A- in 61b and 70, which is honestly crazy for someone with no prior experience. I think it is a bit delicate because there is simply too much people who want to do CS and it is hard to find a way of restricting the major to the ones that really want it.

So, you might be incredibly talented but might only want to do the major to land a job offer and get $$$ and might not really like the field. On the other end you might be incredibly passionate about the field but not have awesome grades. The first student might end up with three A- and the second one might miss the cut-off by falling short by half a letter step in CS70. This for me is very disheartening, especially if the second person really tried hard from 61a into 61b and then was full-stoped at 70. Ofc, the first person should not be stopped from declaring because he is capable and we cannot interrogate everyone with a magnifying glass and simply kick out everyone who does not breathe CS. But at the same time it is sad for me to see the second person to miss out of the major. This is not something I feel happens in purpose nor something caused specifically by Berkeley EECS, but it is still a situation that might occur. People will say "just appeal" but in my head that is just not right. You are barring a deeply interested individual from granted admission into their passion while you let in people that scored slightly better than him but that might not be so in love with the subject. And the person might not get in in the end (and if he ends up under 3.2 the appeal is no longer a solution)

not to mention the gpa cutoff is classist, because anyone who's had the resources to take Computer Science classes in high school can come in and do way better than harder working more motivated kids simply by virtue of having more exposure. the fact that the University continues to propagate these class differences after admitting students is enraging.

Honestly I feel like the above comment is a bit overstated. While, yes, those with prior experience have more of an advantage than those who were not privileged enough to have prior experience, the cutoff isn't "top 20% of applicants" or something like that (which would actually have implications of classism). The GPA cutoff is brutal and yes it does suck to have to have it, but that's a byproduct of the demand for the CS major being so high that the department can only realistically support so many students with the money the university provides. I was not fortunate enough to have CS classes while I was in high school and had no prior experience aside from a couple of Codecademy courses that I did a week before classes started. With that said, declaring was an extreme struggle for me and I barely made it. I agree with the sentiment that there are so many aspects of the cutoff that seem unfair and/or prejudiced towards certain groups of people, but the department is between a rock and a hard place when it comes to this, making this essentially a necessary evil.

Honestly the GPA cutoff is really disheartening to me, I would have never made it as a CS major if I came in just one year later due to the GPA cutoff raising.... and it took me a while to really start to understand and appreciate CS and I just kept working hard (didn't have programming experience coming in and didn't think I was going to be CS Major) and I have done much better in my upper division classes than the lower division ones...

I understand why the GPA cutoff is needed but I just feel disappointed for those similar to me who started off slow but are capable of finding success later by keeping at it and don't get the chance to show that if they can't make the major.
